about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
In Khan et al. (2020), a retrospective analysis of 269 patients ≥18 years old diagnosed with TBI from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2016 admitted to UCHealth Memorial Hospital Central (Colorado Springs, CO), Loyola University Medical Center (Maywood, Illinois), Medical Center of the Rockies (Loveland, CO) was performed. They were identified by trauma registry or electronic medical record. All patients ≥18 years old from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2016 with findings of an ICH or skull fracture on initial head CT scan and no abnormalities on neurologic examination were included in the study.

Exclusion criteria were the following:

  • Patients meeting BIG 3 criteria.
  • Patients with penetrating injuries.
  • Patients who presented greater than 48 hours after injury.
  • Patients transferred from outside hospitals without available images from initial CT.
  • Patients with previous brain operations.
  • Patients intubation within the first 6 hours of presentation.
  • Patients in which withdrawal of care or comfort measures were initiated within the first 48 hours of presentation.
  • Patients with missing values.
  • Patients who did not receive a repeat head CT.

Khan et al. demonstrated that the BIG criteria was accurate in identifying low-risk TBI patients at the three institutions. Multivariable logistic regression identified EDH (p = 0.033) and IPH (p = 0.026) as independent predictors of progression/worsening of injury.

The strengths of this study included the following:

  • Multicenter study.
  • mBIG criteria identified all low risk patients.
  • Application of criteria could result in substantial savings cost and resource utilization in the treatment of TBI patients.

There were a few areas of improvement noted by the authors such as:

  • Study was a retrospective, database study, reliant on correct coding and subject to variability in patient management across providers and institutions.
  • Not prospectively validated.

Khan et al. (2022) was a multicenter review of prospectively collected data with historical control. The study consisted of 764 patients total at 3 trauma centers, 496 in the post mBIG implementation cohort and 268 from a historical cohort. It included patients who were older than 15 years old with an ICH or skull fracture on CT scan. Exclusion criteria included patients with an mBIG 3 classification, intubation, previous operation on the brain or skull, penetrating injury, transfers from outside hospitals without available images, patients who presented more than 48 hours from injury.

Khan et al. (2022) found that:

  • Fewer computed tomography scans (2 [1,2] vs. 2 [2,3], p < 0.0001) and neurosurgery consults (61.9% vs. 95.9%, p < 0.0001) were obtained post-mBIG implementation vs pre-BIG cohort.
  • Hospital (2 [1,4] vs. 2 [2,4], p = 0.013) and intensive care unit (0 [0,1] vs. 1 [1,2], p < 0.0001) length of stay were shorter after mBIG implementation.
  • No statistical difference seen between groups in rate of clinical (1.6% vs. 0.4%, p = 0.172), radiographic progression (13.2% vs. 11.9%, p = 0.650), neurosurgery operative intervention (0.2% vs. 1.1%, p = 0.127), or mortality (0.2% vs. 0%, p = 0.999). 

No difference was seen in the rate of clinical or radiographic progression, neurosurgery operations, or mortality between the two groups. The strength of this study was its multicenter nature.

Areas for improvement in future work include:

  • Combined prospective and retrospective cohort with use of historical controls.
  • As a multicenter trial, differences in practice patterns between the institutions may confound findings.

Azim et al. (2017) was a prospective cohort study with historical control to evaluate use of the mBIG criteria for the management of pediatric TBI patients with ICH without neurosurgical consult (NC). Subanalysis based on patient age showed a decrease in the use of repeat head CT (p = 0.02) in the no-NC group, with no difference in progression (p = 0.34) and the need for neurosurgical intervention (p = 0.9) compared with the NC group. Authors concluded that mBIG can be safely implemented in pediatric TBI patients.
about.formula_en: EDH: epidural hematoma, EtOH: blood alcohol level, GCS: Glasgow Coma Score, ICH: intracranial hemorrhage, IPH: intraparenchymal hemorrhage, IVH: intraventricular hemorrhage, SAH: subarachnoid hemorrhage, SDH: subdural hematoma, TBI: traumatic brain injury

Original/Primary Reference.text: Khan AD, Elseth AJ, Brosius JA, et al. Multicenter assessment of the Brain Injury Guidelines and a proposal of guideline modifications. Trauma Surg Acute Care Open. 2020;5(1):e000483.

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: The mBIG criteria was developed to help physicians determine treatment and disposition for patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) or intracranial hemorrhage (ICH).
how_to_use.use_case_en: Traumatic brain injury patients with intracranial hemorrhage, Glasgow Coma Score 13-15, and no focal neurologic or pupillary findings.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• In 2013, TBI was diagnosed in more than 2.8 million ED visits and 282,000 hospital admissions and an estimated cost to the US healthcare system of $76.5 billion in 2010.
  • The mBIG criteria was developed to help physicians determine which patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) or intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) need hospital admission, repeat head CT or neurosurgical consult.

next_steps.management_en:
mBIG 1:

  • No hospital admission.
  • 6 hr ED observation.
  • No repeat head CT.
  • No neurosurgery consult.
  • Q2 neurological assessment.
  • Trauma team assessment at 3 hrs.
  • Attending assessment at 6 hrs.
  • GCS 15 for discharge.

mBIG 2:

  • Hospital admission to general medical floor for 24-48 hrs.
  • No repeat head CT.
  • No neurosurgery consult.
  • Q2 neurological assessment.
  • Trauma team assessment at 3 hrs.
  • Attending assessment at 6-12 hrs.
  • GCS 15 for discharge.

mBIG 3:

  • Continue with standard of care at your institution.

creators.about_en: Abid D. Khan, MD, is a general surgeon and intensive care medicine doctor in Colorado Springs, Colorado. He is a participant in the Medicare Physician Quality Reporting System (PQRS) Incentive Program and is committed to heart health through the Million Hearts initiative. Dr. Khan’s primary research is focused on trauma and critical care.

cme_faq.answer: MDCalc’s Continuing Medical Education (CME) service allows users to easily earn AMA PRA Category 1 CreditsTM through regular use of MDCalc. Simply put, on top of getting the best medical calculators in the world, your usage will help you achieve your annual CME requirements, including specialty CME, without any extra effort.
cme_faq.question: What is MDCalc CME?

cme_faq.answer: Yes, in support of improving patient care, this activity has been planned and implemented by the Postgraduate Institute for Medicine and MDCalc Ltd. Inc. Postgraduate Institute for Medicine is jointly accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE), and the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), to provide continuing education for the healthcare team.
cme_faq.question: Is MDCalc CME accredited?

cme_faq.answer: Only United States attending physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and physician assistants are eligible for our CME service.
cme_faq.question: Who can enroll and how?

cme_faq.answer: We have over 275 CME-eligible calculators across various specialties. You can read the clinical content supporting any CME calculators to start earning. Once you have viewed all the supporting content for a calculator, you will have officially earned the credit amount (0.5 credits) and will be able to redeem a certificate. For now, only calc content in CME-eligible calcs is eligible for CME credits, however, we’ll be expanding our CME service to include more of our content in the future.
cme_faq.question: What activities can I do to earn CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: Simply use our search bar or visit our homepage to easily find CME-eligible calcs. You must be enrolled in our CME service to see which calcs are CME-eligible.
cme_faq.question: Where can I find calcs with which I can earn credits?

cme_faq.answer: Once you’ve enrolled in our CME service, you will have a personal CME Dashboard where you can view all of your earned credits. You can navigate to the dashboard by clicking the CME button in the header at the top of any page.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see which credits I’ve earned?

cme_faq.answer: Go to your CME Dashboard and select the credits you’d like to redeem, fill out a few dropdown answers about how you used the calc, and then proceed to checkout.
cme_faq.question: How do I redeem CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: No. Earning credits as you use calcs is free, but either you (or your employer) will need to purchase an annual subscription to redeem your CME certificates.
cme_faq.question: Are CME credits free?

cme_faq.answer: Just like with earned credits, you can view your CME certificates on your CME Dashboard in the “CME Certificates” tab. Certificates include a list of all of the calcs for which CME was earned along with a tally of the specialty CME.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see my CME certificates?

cme_faq.answer: One year from the date of purchase.
cme_faq.question: How long do credits in an annual subscription last?

cme_faq.answer: General; Addiction and Controlled Substances; Cardiac Care; Domestic and Intimate Partner Violence; Geriatrics; HIV and Infectious Disease; Hospice, End-of-Life, Terminal Illness, and Palliative Care; Mental and Behavioral Health; Pain Management; Pediatrics; Stroke; and Trauma.
cme_faq.question: What specialty CME credits are included in the plan?

cme_faq.answer:
Your gift card will be sent via email within 1-2 business days of making your purchase. You will be able to select from the following options - Visa, Amazon.com, Apple. Be sure to claim your gift card offer within 90 days of receiving the email.

Your CME purchase may have implications for tax reporting purposes. The cost of your CME product may or may not be tax-deductible when used for professional purposes. Any reimbursed amount for incentives must be declared as personal income for tax purposes. Please consult your tax advisor. MDCalc does not provide tax advice.
cme_faq.question: I ordered a CME package with a gift card. How does it work?

cme_faq.answer: Per the new guidelines from ACCME, the receipt will separate the cost you paid into the cost of the gift card and the cost of the CME learning activity.
cme_faq.question: What will show on my receipt for CME when it includes a gift card?

cme_faq.answer: You can get a refund (minus any promotional gift amount) within 30-days if the ease of earning and redeeming does not meet your expectations and if you have redeemed no more than 4 credits. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request a refund.
cme_faq.question: How do I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

cme_faq.answer: You can upgrade your subscription throughout your billing cycle and pay the difference for a higher plan. You may request to downgrade your plan to a lower level to coincide with your next renewal. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request changes.
cme_faq.question: How do I later upgrade to a different plan if I need more credits?

cme_faq.answer: Gift card plans are available for 1 year and do not auto-renew. Standard, non gift-card subscriptions are auto-renewed annually. You can disable the automatic renewal of your subscription at any time by emailing team@mdcalc.com.
cme_faq.question: Do CME plans auto-renew?

cme_faq.answer: If you’re part of a team or practice that wants to sign up five or more physicians, please email us at team@mdcalc.com for more information.
cme_faq.question: How do I get information on a discounted bulk subscription program for my institution, team, or practice?

cme_faq.answer: On July 28, 2022, ACCME updated the guidelines regarding the use of high-value incentives. These guidelines allow for the use of gift card rewards in a regulated manner. Visit the ACCME website to read their guidelines.
cme_faq.question: Did the ACCME decide to regulate gift cards?
